awd_titl_txt: Conference: FOCS Conference Student and Postdoc Travel Support
awd_abstract_narration:
The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) is one of the premier annual research conferences that cover the breadth of theoretical computer science. It is a conference of very long standing that has continued to play a formative role in the field; it is also at the leading edge of connections made to other areas. This project aims to increase the impact of this conference on students and postdoctoral researchers, particularly those from under-represented groups, by encouraging and enabling their participation, especially in cases where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance.

Concretely, this project assists students and postdoctoral fellows in attending the 2023 Annual FOCS conference, sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Mathematical Foundations of Computing (TCMF). The coming FOCS will take place in Santa Cruz, CA, November 6-9, 2023. As computing becomes ubiquitous, it is crucial to expand the participation of young scholars in cutting-edge research. FOCS has served as one of the most important venues for groundbreaking research in theoretical computer science – and, increasingly, as a key ambassador to other areas within and outside computer science. We anticipate the conference presentations and discussions will expose students and postdoctoral researchers to a broad set of fundamental questions and ideas. We expect the community to benefit in turn, as such junior researchers have contributed substantially to the growth of theoretical computer science over the years. With an emphasis on junior scholars in need, supporting the participation of junior researchers from underrepresented populations in the stimulating exchange of ideas benefits all conference attendees. As the tools and techniques from theoretical computer science (such as novel models, algorithms, impossibility results, and unexpected connections in data science and machine learning) are becoming vital to several domains inside and outside computer science, it is anticipated that such broader participation of junior researchers will benefit society at large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this grant, written in my role as the Chair of IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Mathematical Foundations of Computing (TCMF), is to assist students/postdocs to attend the 2023 Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) at Santa Cruz California. The goal is to encourage and enable the participation of students/postdocs in cases where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance. With priority given to support young scholars from under-represented groups, broadening the participation will benefit students in need as well as strengthen the long-term robustness and diversity of this top conference.

We received $20,000 from NSF for FOCS’23, which was used to support students/postdocs to attend FOCS’23, which was successfully held as the second in-person FOCS after Covid.

It has been a wonderful experience interacting with many talented young researchers in TCS and their advisors in many universities to understand their excitement about the research fields and their needs. I hope these experiences will contribute to future collaboration between NSF and TCS conferences, particularly in areas of supporting NSF's goals for recruiting a diverse spectrum of participants.

Intellectual Merit:

With the rise of the Internet and Big Data, computer science is now at the center of many disciplines, from natural sciences to social sciences, from medicine to art, from engineering to policy. As these interactions emerge, theoretical computer scientists, particularly the younger generation, have taken great strides in advancing algorithmic/computational thinking beyond our traditional field. The NSF travel award has been making direct contributions to this generation.

IEEE FOCS is one of the two premier TCS conferences, with a long standing that has continued to play a formative role in the field; it is also at the leading edge of connections made to other fields.

For FOCS’23, we received near record high 43 applications. Because many advisors indicated that they would find ways to support their students, in case they didn’t receive any travel award, we were able to partly support all students/postdocs who had papers in FOCS 2023. In total, we (partly) supported 34 students/postdocs from 16 different universities. 

We believe that the resultant discussions will expose the awardees to a broad set of fundamental questions and ideas. With a strong aim to support young research from underrepresented groups and talented students beyond traditional TCS powerhouses, our goal is to broaden the participation to make FOCS an even more robust TCS conference. We expect the research community to benefit in turn, as such junior researchers have contributed substantially to the growth of theoretical computer science over the years.

Broader Impacts: 

Built on the NSF FOCS travel grants, we also applied and received support from Akamai and Google.

Working with TCS Women and a Google DEI grant that we received, we provided FULL support to 6 women applicants. By supporting applicants from more than 16 universities, the funds were widely distributed among many universities beyond just traditional TCS powerhouses.

Working with NSF and young researchers in this selection process provided us valuable experience to be more proactive in reaching out to TCS women community/organizations to encourage female theoretical computer scientists about future NSF FOCS travel grants. 

Many of the Ph.D. students/postdocs supported by NSF FOCS travel grants will be future leaders in computer science. Several have already made breakthrough discoveries in algorithm design and computational complexity by solving long-term fundamental open questions. The NSF travel award, particularly at this stage of their professional career, are critical support to their growth. In addition to helping them to participate in the premier conferences to benefit them and the research community, the application process also helped them to recognize how much their research is supported by not just their advisors/institutes, but by society in large.

Acknowledgement: USC Computer Science Department’s business office provided complimentary support for managing the entire process of reimbursements involving this NSF grant, so that all funds can be used for student/postdoc travel to attend FOCS. We greatly appreciate their contribution and generosity.

Modified by: Shanghua Teng
